chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Ernest D Atchison was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Ernest D Atchison is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Ernest D Atchison was found guilty of Criminal Damage to Property (Over $2500) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(2)(d).
  • Ernest D Atchison was found guilty of Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Concurrent with: 14CF372 - Count 6
Sentence in Minnesota

superMiscConds.notes: $10,819.72 Restitution, plus 10% surcharge of $1,081.97, for a total of $11,901.69, to be paid to the Department of Corrections during Initial Confinement or Extended Supervision.  Failure to pay may result in a tax intercept, license suspension, warrant and/or civil judgment.
$250.00 DNA surcharge to be paid to the Department of Corrections during Extended Supervision.  Failure to pay may result in a warrant, tax intercept, license suspension and/or civil judgment.
May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  If not a U.S. Citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.

Must write apology letter to Ryan Ludy if Agent requires it during Extended Supervision.
Defendant must avail himself of programming in Minnesota system.
Must provide a DNA sample.  Under Wisconsin Statute 165.76, you are required to provide a biological specimen to the Wisconsin Department of Justice for deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) testing.  If you fail to provide a DNA sample, you may be held in contempt and subject to sanctions or charged with a new crime.
